content: rainbow indigo fisherman s beanie this is the sixth in a series of hats designed during the coronavirus pandemic of 2020 the complete series includes one hat in each colour of the rainbow a symbol representing hope during a dark time in our lives made bearable by the spirit of resilience and fellow feeling of family friends neighbours and complete strangers this hat was inspired by the traditional ganseys or sweaters worn for centuries by the fishermen of the north-east coast of the uk near where i live each fishing community had its own combination of patterns legend having it that any drowned sailor could be identified by his sweater the patterns on the sweaters represented elements of the seafaring life ropes flags anchors ladders steps paths nets etc this particular pattern has cables representing ropes diamonds representing fishing nets and textured stitches representing ladders originally knit in 5 ply gansey wool in the round on long double pointed needles the sweaters were knit to a very tight gauge helping to block the wind and rain of the high seas gansey wool is available even now from specialist suppliers but tends to be expensive to make it more accessible to the modern knitter this hat is knit in pure wool dk on circular needles to a tighter gauge than usual because of the large number of stitches to each repeat of the design it is only practical to offer it in one size a smaller or larger hat could be achieved by using smaller or larger needles to a different gauge size to fit a head circumference of approx 22 56cm unblocked circumference 18 43cm to fit head depth approx 9 23cm actual depth of crown to cast on 10¼ 26cm gauge 26st and 36 row in stocking stitch on 3 25mm needles materials 2x 50g balls drops karisma dk yarn in navy blue 17 colourway or 2 x 50g balls drops flora in indigo knit with 2 strands held together on 3 25mm needles gives a slightly smaller size 3 25mm short circular needle 3 25mm double pointed needles dpns cable needle 4 stitch markers darning needle hat brim using 3 25mm short circular needles cast on 140st join to knit in the round taking care not to twist the stitches place a marker to denote the start of the round there are more stitches than you would expect because this hat is knit to achieve a dense fabric work 4 10cm in k1 p1 rib if you need to adjust the overall length of the hat do it here on the last rib round increase the number of stitches evenly by 8st 148st the increase falls around the 17/18th stitch main body of the hat beginning at round1 work the 16 row of chart a twice each panel is repeated four times across the round now work all the rounds of chart b to the end 12st remaining break yarn and thread the tail through a darning needle
